title: Silver Dollar City battles for naming rights with man who turned garage into haunted house
text:
Court filings indicate Silver Dollar City, a Branson, Missouri-area theme park, is in a legal battle over naming rights with a man who once turned part of his suburban California home into a seasonal haunted house attraction.

Back in August, Silver Dollar City announced it is building a $23 million expansion that includes a water ride called "Mystic River Falls."

Documents filed earlier this month in federal court say that a man named Scott D'Avanzo is trying to block the Branson-area theme park from using the Mystic River Falls name, claiming it is too similar to the name D'Avanzo gave to the haunted house attraction he created out of his Orange County, California, home in 2013 called Mystic Motel, reports the Springfield News-Leader, which is part of the USA TODAY Network.

Silver Dollar City announced Mystic River Falls as their new ride on Tuesday, Aug. 13, 2019. (Photo: Sara Karnes/News-Leader)

D'Avanzo is demanding Silver Dollar City change the name of its new ride to avoid confusion and unfair competition, according to court filings.

Silver Dollar City responded with a lawsuit this month, saying it went through the necessary steps to register the Mystic River Falls mark with the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office, and D'Avanzo did not oppose Silver Dollar City's application during the requisite opposition period.

In the lawsuit, Silver Dollar City indicates it does not believe there will be confusion between its multimillion-dollar ride and the haunted house D'Avanzo created in the attached garage of his home as a "family project and neighborhood attraction."

Related: Silver Dollar City announces major park expansion, Mystic River Falls

The lawsuit says D'Avanzo's Mystic Motel haunted house is no longer operational, and the Mystic Motel name doesn't appear to be in use.

Silver Dollar City's Mystic River Falls ride is scheduled to open in summer 2020.

Silver Dollar City says the name Mystic River Falls is an ode to the theme park's origin centered around Marvel Cave, which contains the Mystic River Passage and Mystic River Pool Room.

The Mystic River Falls ride will replace the old Lost River of the Ozarks water ride, and it boasts the "the tallest drop on a raft ride in the Western Hemisphere."

More: Marvel Cave: a natural wonder and an inspiration for growth at Silver Dollar City

In the recent filings, Silver Dollar City says it has "extensively advertised and promoted" its new water ride using the Mystic River Falls name and it does not believe D'Avanzo's claim should force the theme park to change the name of its new water ride.

An attempt to reach D'Avanzo's attorney for comment was not successful.

Silver Dollar City spokeswoman Lisa Rau said the organization is aware of the court filings but did not have a comment since it is a legal matter.

Meanwhile, in New Jersey: American Dream Nickelodeon Universe giant indoor theme park sells out for first weekend

description: Silver Dollar City's Mystic River Falls is expected to open in summer 2020, but a California man claims the name is too similar to his haunted house.
